issue.title: Recent pytest now issues a warning with our conftest.py, breaking our CI
issue.body:
See: https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/issues/4039

And since we use `-W error`, this breaks everything in CI...

body: @njsmith technically for python its not at the toplevel - i propose defining an addopts = -p pytester in the pytest/tox.ini
@RonnyPfannschmidt But pytest.ini/tox.ini aren't part of the package, so you can't effectively use them with the tests-inside-package layout.
...so are you saying that you're dropping support for the tests-inside-package layout, or...?

@njsmith pytest never had reasonable support for tests inside package to begin with - and you just see the effect of that because we drop something unrelated that is completely broken yet it messes your setup
@njsmith we do support tests-inside-package layouts, so we will need to figure out a proper way to solve this problem. I'm facing this problem myself in a few internal packages at work.

@nicoddemus i'd like to note that those layouts only work mostly by accident and matching path collection - pytest is pretty much __bad__ about it and we need an actual tool to have such collections work reasonably

Noted, but either way we need to find a reasonable way to fix this; the `pytest_plugins` is correctly at the top of the package, so pytest is emitting a false warning. I would rather drop the warning altogether until we find a reasonable solution, for example.

we might want to drop the warning if the "toplevel" is inside a python package imported as python package from a actual import location

but part of that is correctly working with pyimport and figuring a sane path towards import and collection roots (because what we have right now is just `find++`)

> we might want to drop the warning if the "toplevel" is inside a python package imported as python package from a actual import location

This might be a reasonable temporary workaround.

> but part of that is correctly working with pyimport and figuring a sane path towards import and collection roots (because what we have right now is just find++)

Agreed.

issue.title: Make --pyargs properly import modules

repository.name: pytest
repository.description: The pytest framework makes it easy to write small tests, yet scales to support complex functional testing

issue.body:
As discussed in https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/issues/4039, currently all `--pyargs` does is locating files/directories based on `sys.path`, and once finding that filenames pytest proceeds as usual.

We should instead properly import the modules based on what has been passed using `pyimport`/`__import__`. This would be more consistent and would permit to run tests from modules that are importable but are otherwise not on a file on disk.
